tier_0_classification.classification_reasoning: This is a numerical calculation problem involving isentropic efficiency and temperature rise across compressor stages. It requires multiple steps to calculate the overall temperature rise and then determine the number of stages, integrating concepts of thermodynamics and compressor performance.

answer_validation.reasoning:
Overall isentropic efficiency \(\eta_c = 0.83\), inlet stagnation temperature \(T_{t1} = 300\,	ext{K}\), overall pressure ratio \(\pi_c = 10\). For a compressor, 

1) Isentropic exit stagnation temperature for the given pressure ratio: 


$$T_{t3s} = T_{t1} \pi_c^{(\gamma-1)/\gamma}$$
With \(\gamma = 1.4\), \((\gamma-1)/\gamma = 0.4/1.4 \approx 0.2857\).


\(10^{0.2857} \approx 1.93\), so \(T_{t3s} \approx 300 	imes 1.93 \approx 579\,	ext{K}.\)

2) Actual exit stagnation temperature using overall isentropic efficiency definition for a compressor: 


$$\eta_c =  rac{T_{t3s} - T_{t1}}{T_{t3} - T_{t1}}$$

Rearrange to get \(T_{t3}\):


$$T_{t3} - T_{t1} =  rac{T_{t3s} - T_{t1}}{\eta_c}$$


\(T_{t3s} - T_{t1} = 579 - 300 = 279\,	ext{K}\). Thus,


$$T_{t3} - 300 =  rac{279}{0.83} \approx 336.1\,	ext{K}$$

So \(T_{t3} \approx 300 + 336.1 = 636.1\,	ext{K}.\)

3) Total stagnation temperature rise across the whole compressor: 


$$\Delta T_{t,	ext{overall}} = T_{t3} - T_{t1} \approx 336.1\,	ext{K}$$

4) Each stage is similar and has a stagnation temperature rise of 20 K. If there are \(N\) stages: 


$$N 	imes 20 = 336.1 \Rightarrow N =  rac{336.1}{20} \approx 16.8$$

The nearest integer (and the only reasonable option) is 17 stages. Hence option A is consistent with the thermodynamic relations and the given data.

step_by_step: Identify given data: overall isentropic efficiency \(\eta_c = 0.83\), inlet stagnation temperature \(T_{t1} = 300\,\text{K}\), overall pressure ratio \(\pi_c = 10\), per-stage stagnation temperature rise \(\Delta T_{t,\text{stage}} = 20\,\text{K}\), \(\gamma = 1.4\).
Compute the isentropic exit stagnation temperature for the given pressure ratio using \(T_{t3s} = T_{t1} \pi_c^{(\gamma-1)/\gamma}\).
Use the compressor isentropic efficiency definition \(\eta_c = (T_{t3s} - T_{t1})/(T_{t3} - T_{t1})\) to find the actual exit stagnation temperature \(T_{t3}\).
Calculate the overall stagnation temperature rise: \(\Delta T_{t,\text{overall}} = T_{t3} - T_{t1}\).
Relate the overall temperature rise to the number of identical stages: \(\Delta T_{t,\text{overall}} = N \times \Delta T_{t,\text{stage}}\), and solve for \(N\).
Round \(N\) to the nearest integer and match with the closest option.

topic.name: Gas turbine compressors and efficiencies
topic.syllabus_ref: Section 6 Propulsion -> Gas turbine engines: compressors and turbines

concepts.name: Stagnation temperature and pressure relations for isentropic compression

essential: Definition of stagnation (total) temperature and pressure
Isentropic relations for ideal gases in compressors
Concept of multi-stage compression and per-stage temperature rise
helpful: Understanding of axial compressor stage similarity
Thermodynamic T-s diagram for compression processes

Main Concept: requires: Isentropic relations for ideal gases
requires: Definition and use of compressor isentropic efficiency
enables: Estimating number of stages for a required pressure ratio
enables: Preliminary design of multi-stage axial compressors

difficulty_factors: Requires correct use of compressor efficiency definition (actual vs isentropic temperature rise)
Needs careful handling of the exponent in the isentropic temperature relation
Students may be tempted to ignore efficiency and simply divide total temperature rise from isentropic relation by per-stage rise

textbook_references.book: Modern Compressible Flow with Historical Perspective
textbook_references.author: John D. Anderson
textbook_references.chapter_title: Compressible Flow Through Nozzles, Diffusers, and Compressors

textbook_references.author: V. Ganesan
textbook_references.text_snippet: Compressor isentropic efficiency relates the ideal isentropic temperature rise to the actual temperature rise for a given pressure ratio.

video_references.topic_covered: Axial flow compressor stage temperature rise, stage pressure ratio, and stage efficiency
Compressor isentropic efficiency and relation between pressure ratio and temperature ratio

step_by_step_solution.solution_path: Isentropic temperature relation \u2192 Efficiency relation \u2192 Actual temperature rise \u2192 Sum over stages
key_insights: Overall isentropic efficiency connects the ideal and actual stagnation temperature rises for the same pressure ratio.
Once the overall actual stagnation temperature rise is known, identical stage temperature rise allows a simple division to get the number of stages.
Pressure ratio per stage is not needed explicitly because the per-stage temperature rise is directly given.

formulas_principles.name: Isentropic stagnation temperature relation for compressor
formulas_principles.conditions: Applies to ideal isentropic compression of an ideal gas with constant gamma across a compressor with overall pressure ratio pi_c.
formulas_principles.relevance: Used to find the ideal exit stagnation temperature for the given pressure ratio.

formulas_principles.name: Compressor isentropic efficiency
formulas_principles.conditions: Applies to adiabatic compressors where efficiency is defined based on stagnation temperatures for a given pressure ratio.
formulas_principles.relevance: Relates ideal and actual temperature rises to compute the actual exit stagnation temperature.

formulas_principles.name: Total stagnation temperature rise across multi-stage compressor
formulas_principles.conditions: Valid when all stages are similar and each stage has the same stagnation temperature rise.
formulas_principles.relevance: Directly used to compute the number of stages from the overall temperature rise.

formulas_principles.name: Specific heat at constant pressure for ideal gas
formulas_principles.conditions: Ideal gas with constant gamma; not numerically needed here but underlies temperature-enthalpy relation.
formulas_principles.relevance: Connects temperature rise to enthalpy rise and work, conceptually explaining why temperature rise per stage is a measure of work input.

industry_examples: Preliminary design of multi-stage axial compressors in turbofan engines, where engineers estimate the number of stages needed to achieve a target overall pressure ratio with given stage loading and efficiency.
Performance analysis and retrofit decisions for existing gas turbine compressors, where measured overall efficiency and pressure ratio can be used to infer per-stage loading and possible redesign.
specific_systems: High-bypass turbofan engines used in commercial airliners (e.g., CFM56, LEAP), which employ multi-stage axial compressors with carefully chosen per-stage temperature rise.
Industrial gas turbines for power generation, where compressor design strongly affects overall cycle efficiency.
real_world_applications.practical_relevance: Accurate estimation of the number of compressor stages is crucial for engine weight, cost, and efficiency. Overestimating stages increases complexity and weight; underestimating may prevent achieving the required pressure ratio or cause excessive stage loading and stall issues.

common_mistakes.mistake: Using the isentropic temperature relation to get T_{t3s} and then directly dividing (T_{t3s} - T_{t1}) by per-stage temperature rise, ignoring the overall isentropic efficiency.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They remember the pressure-temperature relation but forget that efficiency makes the actual temperature rise larger than the isentropic one.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Always ask: Is the process ideal or real? If an efficiency is given, use it to connect ideal and actual temperatures before doing any stage-wise calculation.
common_mistakes.consequence: Underestimates the number of stages, giving a smaller N than correct.

common_mistakes.mistake: Misapplying the efficiency formula as \(\eta_c = (T_{t3} - T_{t1})/(T_{t3s} - T_{t1})\) instead of its correct inverse.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Confusion between turbine and compressor efficiency definitions or mixing up numerator and denominator.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Memorize the physical meaning: for a compressor, actual temperature rise is larger than isentropic, so efficiency must be less than 1, meaning the isentropic rise is in the numerator.
common_mistakes.consequence: Leads to a smaller actual temperature rise and hence an incorrect, smaller number of stages.

common_mistakes.mistake: Numerical error in computing \(10^{(\\gamma-1)/\\gamma}\), such as using 10^0.4 instead of 10^0.2857.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They forget to divide by gamma or misread the exponent.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Write the exponent explicitly as (gamma - 1)/gamma and compute step by step; check that the exponent is less than 1.
common_mistakes.consequence: Gives wrong isentropic exit temperature and propagates to an incorrect number of stages.

common_mistakes.mistake: Rounding intermediate values too aggressively (e.g., using T_{t3s} = 580 K and efficiency 0.8 instead of 0.83).
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Trying to simplify mental arithmetic under time pressure.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Keep at least 2–3 significant figures in intermediate steps; only round at the final answer, especially when options are close.
common_mistakes.consequence: May shift N enough to choose a neighboring option if the values are borderline.

mnemonics_memory_aids.mnemonic: For Compressors: Cool (C) on top, Hot (H) below: \(\eta_c = (T_{t3s}-T_{t1})/(T_{t3}-T_{t1})\). Ideal (cooler) rise on top, actual (hotter) rise below.
mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: Correct form of compressor isentropic efficiency relation
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: Use when recalling whether ideal or actual temperature rise goes in the numerator for compressors.

mnemonics_memory_aids.mnemonic: I before A: Isentropic before Actual. For compressors, efficiency = Isentropic rise / Actual rise.
mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: Ordering of terms in efficiency definition
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: Quick recall during exams when writing efficiency formulas.

flashcards.front: Write the isentropic stagnation temperature relation for an ideal gas compressor with pressure ratio \(\\pi_c\).
flashcards.back: For an ideal isentropic compressor: \n\n\(T_{t3s} = T_{t1} \\pi_c^{(\\gamma-1)/\\gamma}\).

flashcards.front: Define compressor isentropic efficiency in terms of stagnation temperatures.
flashcards.back: Compressor isentropic efficiency: \n\n\(\\eta_c = (T_{t3s} - T_{t1}) / (T_{t3} - T_{t1})\), where 1→3s is isentropic and 1→3 is actual for the same pressure ratio.

flashcards.front: An axial compressor has identical stages, each giving a 15 K stagnation temperature rise. If overall \(\\Delta T_t = 300\,K\), how many stages?
flashcards.back: Number of stages \(N = \\Delta T_{t,overall} / \\Delta T_{t,stage} = 300 / 15 = 20\) stages.

flashcards.front: For a real compressor with given pressure ratio, is \(T_{t3}\) greater or smaller than \(T_{t3s}\)? Why?
flashcards.back: For a real compressor, \(T_{t3} > T_{t3s}\) because irreversibilities (friction, losses) require more work, leading to a larger actual temperature rise for the same pressure ratio.

flashcards.front: In compressor efficiency, which goes in the numerator: isentropic or actual temperature rise?
flashcards.back: Isentropic temperature rise goes in the numerator: \(\\eta_c = (T_{t3s} - T_{t1}) / (T_{t3} - T_{t1})\).

real_world_context.application: Design of multi-stage axial compressors in aircraft engines
real_world_context.industry_example: In a modern turbofan, the high-pressure compressor may have 8–10 stages, each adding a controlled stagnation temperature rise (e.g., 20–30 K) to reach an overall pressure ratio above 10:1.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Incorrect estimation of stage count or per-stage loading can lead to compressor stall, reduced efficiency, or excessive engine weight and cost.

real_world_context.application: Upgrading industrial gas turbines for higher efficiency
real_world_context.industry_example: Power plant operators may retrofit compressors with improved blade designs to increase stage efficiency, allowing the same pressure ratio with fewer stages or lower work input.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Even a small improvement in compressor efficiency can significantly reduce fuel consumption and operating costs over the turbine's lifetime.

exam_strategy.triage_tip: Scan for given efficiency, inlet temperature, pressure ratio, and per-stage temperature rise. If all are present, it is a straightforward plug-in of isentropic relation and efficiency, then a simple division to get number of stages.
exam_strategy.guessing_heuristic: If stuck, remember that efficiency < 1 makes actual temperature rise larger than isentropic, so the number of stages must be slightly larger than what you get from isentropic rise alone.
exam_strategy.time_management: Aim to finish within 2–3 minutes: 1 minute for isentropic temperature calculation, 1 minute for efficiency step, and 30 seconds to divide by per-stage rise and check options.

search_keywords: multi stage axial compressor design GATE AE
Anderson axial flow compressor stage efficiency

alternative_methods.name: Per-stage pressure ratio approach
alternative_methods.description: Instead of using the given per-stage temperature rise directly, assume each stage has the same pressure ratio. Compute the per-stage pressure ratio as \(\\pi_{stage} = \\pi_c^{1/N}\) for a guessed N, then use stage efficiency and temperature rise relations iteratively to match the given 20 K per stage and overall efficiency.
alternative_methods.pros_cons: Pros: Gives deeper insight into how pressure ratio per stage and efficiency interact. Cons: Iterative and time-consuming; not suitable for an exam MCQ where per-stage temperature rise is already given.
alternative_methods.when_to_use: Useful in design-oriented courses or projects where stage pressure ratios are of interest and numerical tools are available.

connections_to_other_subjects.Thermodynamics: Uses isentropic relations and efficiency definitions directly from basic thermodynamics of compressible flows.
connections_to_other_subjects.Fluid Mechanics: Axial compressor operation depends on blade aerodynamics, velocity triangles, and flow turning, which are fluid mechanics concepts.
connections_to_other_subjects.Heat Transfer: Although compressors are often modeled as adiabatic, real machines have heat transfer with surroundings, affecting performance.
connections_to_other_subjects.Control Systems: Compressor performance maps and surge margins are important in engine control to avoid stall and surge.

deeper_dive_topics: Radial equilibrium and non-uniform radial distribution of axial velocity in axial compressors
Stage loading and flow coefficient design for axial compressor stages
Compressor performance maps and surge line
Effect of variable stator vanes on multi-stage compressor performance

syllabus_mapping.gate_subsection: Gas turbine engines: compressors and turbines, efficiencies and performance
syllabus_mapping.feedback_for_syllabus_design: The question nicely integrates compressor isentropic efficiency with multi-stage axial compressor design, matching the GATE AE propulsion syllabus and testing both conceptual understanding and quick numerical skills.

rag_quality.notes: RAG chunks discussed axial compressor stage temperature rise, stage pressure ratio, and compressor isentropic efficiency, which are directly relevant to this problem. However, the exact multi-stage counting procedure was not explicitly given; internal knowledge was used to connect overall efficiency and per-stage temperature rise to the number of stages.

future_questions_potential: Given the same compressor but a different per-stage temperature rise, ask students to compute the new overall pressure ratio for a fixed number of stages.
Ask for the per-stage pressure ratio and stage isentropic efficiency given overall pressure ratio, overall efficiency, and number of stages.
Include non-identical stages where the first few stages have a different temperature rise and ask for the distribution of temperature or pressure.
Combine compressor and turbine questions: given compressor work and turbine inlet temperature, find required turbine stages or blade speed.

response_json.subject: Aerospace Engineering
response_json.question_text: A multistage axial compressor, with overall isentropic efficiency of 0.83, is used to compress air at a stagnation temperature of 300 K through a pressure ratio of 10:1. Each stage of the compressor is similar, and the stagnation temperature rise across each compressor stage is 20 K. Assume Cp = 1005 J/kg K and gamma = 1.4 for air. How many stages are there in the compressor?
